title: How to Run an ISO File Without Burning

steps.title: Press ⊞ Win+E to open File Explorer.
steps.content: Press ⊞ Win + E to open File Explorer. You can also open File Explorer by right-clicking the Start button and selecting File Explorer .

steps.title: Open the folder that contains the ISO file.
steps.content: Open the folder that contains the ISO file. You may have to double-click This PC in the left panel to expand additional folders before you can find the one you're looking for.

steps.title: Right-click the ISO file.
steps.content: Right-click the ISO file. A context menu will expand.

steps.title: Click Mount on the menu.
steps.content: Click Mount on the menu. This mounts the file, which means Windows will recognize it as a connected drive. If you don't see Mount as an option, follow these steps: Press Windows key + i to open your Windows Settings. Click Apps and select Click Default Apps . Scroll down to the bottom and click Set defaults by app . Select Windows Disc Image and click Manage . [1] X Research source Click the name of the app you see listed as the default and select File Explorer . Return to File Explorer and you should be able to mount the file.

steps.title: Double-click the new drive in the left panel.
steps.content: Double-click the new drive in the left panel. Now that you've mounted the ISO file, you'll see a new virtual drive in the left panel under "This PC" (you may have to double-click This PC to see it). What happens when you double-click the virtual drive depends on the ISO file. For example, if the ISO is an image of a DVD that contains software, you may see a screen asking you to the software when double-clicking it. If there's no automatic installer, you may see a list of folders and files in the right panel—you can explore those files to see what's there and double-click files ending with EXE to run programs. If you want to unmount the ISO, right-click the drive in the left panel and select Eject .

steps.title: Open Finder .
steps.content: Open Finder . It's the two-toned smiley face on the Dock, which is usually at the bottom of the screen.

steps.title: Click the Applications folder.
steps.content: Click the Applications folder. You'll see it in the left panel.

steps.title: Double-click the Utilities folder.
steps.content: Double-click the Utilities folder. It's in the left panel.

steps.title: Double-click Disk Utility.
steps.content: Double-click Disk Utility . It's also in the left panel. This opens the Mac Disk Utility tool.

steps.title: Click the File menu.
steps.content: Click the File menu. It's in the top-left area of the screen.

steps.title: Click Open Disk Image on the menu.
steps.content: Click Open Disk Image on the menu. This opens the file picker.

steps.title: Select your ISO file and click Open.
steps.content: Select your ISO file and click Open . This mounts and opens the ISO file. What happens when you open the ISO depends on what's in the file. For example, if the ISO is set up to run a software installer, it may launch automatically. Usually it'll just open a window containing files, which you can then double-click to open.
